content.text: An instruction to buy or sell a security at a specified price or better.
Gives investors control over the price they pay or receive, rather than executing immediately at the market price.

content.title: Use Cases
items: Avoid overpaying when buying a stock.
Lock in profits by selling only at a desired price.
Plan trades in advance for volatile or fast-moving markets.

content.text: Buying: The order executes only at the limit price or lower.
Selling: The order executes only at the limit price or higher.

content.title: Example
items: Stock XYZ is trading at $50. You want to buy only if it drops to $48. You place a buy limit order at $48. It executes only if the price falls to $48 or lower.
You own Stock ABC at $100 and want to sell if it reaches $110. You place a sell limit order at $110. It executes only at $110 or higher.

content.text: Buy Limit Order: Executes at the limit price or lower.
Sell Limit Order: Executes at the limit price or higher.

content.title: Time Frames
items: Day Order: Expires if not executed by the end of the trading day.
Good Till Cancelled (GTC): Remains active until executed or manually cancelled.

content.text: Partial Fills: In some cases, only part of the order may execute if insufficient shares are available at the limit price.

items: Price Control: Ensures you don’t pay more or sell for less than your target price.
Risk Management: Protects against sudden market spikes or drops.
Strategic Planning: Useful for pre-determined entries and exits without constant monitoring.
Non-Execution Risk: Order may never execute if the market never reaches your limit price.
Partial Fills: Especially in less liquid stocks, only part of your order may be filled.
Opportunity Cost: You might miss out on gains if the price moves past your limit quickly.
Market Volatility: Rapid price changes may result in missed opportunities.
Use limit orders for volatile stocks or markets.
Combine with stop-loss or take-profit strategies for better risk management.
Review and adjust GTC orders periodically to reflect changing market conditions.
Be realistic with your limit prices—setting them too far from the current price reduces chances of execution.
Limit orders provide more control than market orders but require patience.
Best used when you have a specific target price in mind or when avoiding short-term price swings.
Essential tool for disciplined trading, strategic entries/exits, and risk management.
